title: Paper_1107
abstract: pmc J Robot Surg J Robot Surg 365 springeropen Journal of Robotic Surgery 1863-2483 1863-2491 pmc-is-collection-domain yes pmc-collection-title Springer PMC12477092 PMC12477092.1 12477092 12477092 41015968 10.1007/s11701-025-02798-0 2798 1 Research Global research landscape of robotic surgery in gynecologic oncology: a bibliometric analysis (2005–2025) Li Xinshu 1 Li Min 1 2 Cui Huijie 1 2 Du Xinyue 1 Li Bowei 1 Ha Chunfang hachunfang@163.com 2 3 1 https://ror.org/02h8a1848 grid.412194.b 0000 0004 1761 9803 Ningxia Medical University, 2 https://ror.org/02h8a1848 grid.412194.b 0000 0004 1761 9803 Department of Gynecology, General Hospital of Ningxia Medical University, 3 https://ror.org/02h8a1848 grid.412194.b 0000 0004 1761 9803 Key Laboratory of Fertility Preservation & Maintenance of Ministry of Education, Ningxia Medical University, 28 9 2025 2025 19 1 497747 641 13 8 2025 10 9 2025 28 09 2025 30 09 2025 30 09 2025 © The Author(s) 2025 2025 https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Open Access http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ Robotic surgery has transformed gynecologic oncology by enhancing surgical precision and reducing complications, particularly for endometrial, cervical, and ovarian cancers. This study employs bibliometric analysis to systematically evaluate the scientific trajectory, research trends, and international collaboration in robotic surgery for gynecologic malignancies over nearly two decades (2005–2025). Using the Web of Science database, a total of 561 publications were identified and analyzed with Citespace, VOSviewer, and R-bibliometrix. The United States emerged as the most productive nation, with the Università Cattolica del Sacro Cuore (Italy) as the leading institution. The Journal of Gynecologic Oncology published the highest volume of research, and Giovanni Scambia was the most prolific author. Key research themes included endometrial cancer, robotic surgery, laparoscopy, lymphadenectomy, radical hysterectomy, cervical cancer, recurrence, and survival outcomes. Future progress depends on multicenter randomized-controlled trials (RCTs), global partnerships, and AI integration to advance therapeutic potential and promote equitable global access. Keywords Bibliometrics Gynecologic oncology Robotic-assisted surgery VOSviewer Citespace Provincial key research and development program 2023BEG01001 pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement no pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes issue-copyright-statement © Springer-Verlag London Ltd., part of Springer Nature 2025 Introduction Gynecological cancers, including ovarian, endometrial, and cervical cancers, represent a significant global health burden, contributing substantially to cancer-related morbidity and mortality among women worldwide. Surgical intervention remains a cornerstone of curative treatment for many of these cancers, aiming for optimal cytoreduction and accurate staging. The evolution of minimally invasive surgery (MIS) has transformed the surgical landscape, offering benefits such as reduced blood loss, shorter hospital stays, and faster recovery compared to traditional open approaches [ 1 Robotic-assisted surgery, epitomized by the da Vinci Surgical System, has emerged as a prominent technological advancement within minimally invasive surgery (MIS) for gynecological oncology. It offers distinct technical advantages, including enhanced three-dimensional (3D) visualization with magnification, wristed instruments providing greater dexterity and precision in confined anatomical spaces [ 2 3 Despite its widespread adoption, particularly in resource-rich settings, robotic surgery in gynecological oncology is not without significant controversy. Key areas of ongoing debate include its high cost-effectiveness ratio compared to conventional laparoscopy [ 4 5 6 7 8 While numerous narrative and systematic reviews have recently synthesized clinical outcomes data [ 7 9 12 Therefore, this study aims to conduct the comprehensive bibliometric analysis of scientific literature focusing on robotic surgery in gynecological malignancies. Our primary objectives are: 1. To quantify and visualize the global research output trends, including publication volume growth and geographical distribution. 2. To identify and analyze the contributions of leading countries, institutions, and authors, and map their collaborative networks. 3. To determine the core literature (highly cited publications), influential journals, and prolific authors shaping the field. 4. To identify major research themes, hotspots, and emerging frontiers through keyword co-occurrence, clustering, and burst detection analysis. 5. To elucidate the evolution of research focus and predict potential future directions based on the bibliometric evidence. This analysis will provide researchers, clinicians, and policymakers with a data-driven overview of the field's development, highlight areas of strength and gaps in knowledge, and inform strategic planning for future research endeavors. Methods Data sources To ensure the coverage and authority of the data analyzed, the Web of Science (core collection) was selected as the datasource, and the indexes were selected as SSCI and SCI-Expended. The search strategy selected was TS = (("gynecologic* cancer" OR "endometrial cancer" OR "uterine corpus cancer" OR "cervical cancer" OR "ovar* cancer" OR "vaginal cancer") AND ("robot* surger*")), with a time span starting from January 2005 to June 2025, a search time cutoff of June 27,2025, and a literature type selected as “Articles and Review” and a language of English, and 614 literature records were obtained after the search. However, the data directly obtained through the search formula may have some problems such as inconsistency with the subject, so the data need to be pre-processed before the analysis to avoid the results of the analysis due to the quality of the data itself. After the two researchers screened each article, 561 valid documents were finally obtained. Figure 1 Fig. 1 Bibliometric literature screening flowchart Analytical tools R-bibliometrix: CiteSpace: VOSviewer: Scimago Graphica: Results Trend analysis of annual publication volume A corpus of 561 relevant publications was identified for this study. Annual output trends (2005–2025) are illustrated in Fig. 2 Fig. 2 Distribution of publications from 2005 to 2025 Analysis of countries/regions A total of 42 nations contributed to the literature within this domain. Among these, 23 countries and regions have published more than 5 articles. The global distribution of contributions, illustrated on a world map (Fig. 3 1 n n n n n n n n Fig. 3 Geographic distribution of publication counts for countries contributing ≥ 5 articles to robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025 Table 1 Top ten most productive countries in robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025 TP TC Analysis of institution Network analysis revealed significant structural centrality variations among leading institutions. Mayo Clinic exhibited the highest centrality (0.16), indicating its prominent brokerage role in global collaboration networks. Catholic University of the Sacred Heart (0.13) and the University of Texas System (0.12) ranked second and third, respectively (Table 2 Table 2 Top ten leading institutions in robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025 TP PY_start Temporal analysis showed divergent institutional engagement patterns (Fig. 4 Fig. 4 Global institutional landscape of robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025 Analysis of journal A comprehensive bibliometric analysis of robotic surgery literature identified 114 contributing journals. Application of a minimum yield threshold (≥ 5 articles per journal) revealed 29 high-productivity outlets (Fig. 5 3 Fig. 5 Density overlay of publication counts for journals contributing ≥ 5 articles to robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025 Table 3 Top 12 highly productive journals in robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025 TP TC HI GI MI PY_start IF JQ Gynecologic Oncology demonstrated the highest publication volume (71 articles, 12.66%), followed by the International Journal of Gynecological Cancer (45, 8.02%) and the Journal of Minimally Invasive Gynecology (43, 7.66%). Citation analysis showed Gynecologic Oncology as the most influential journal (total citations = 3,649), substantially ahead of the International Journal of Gynecological Cancer (1,224) and the Journal of Minimally Invasive Gynecology (1,219). This dominance was further reflected in the H-index metric (Gynecologic Oncology: h-index = 37 vs. 23 and 21 for the second and third-ranked journals, respectively). The American Journal of Obstetrics & Gynecology held the highest impact factor among leading journals, with the International Journal of Gynecological Cancer (IF = 4.7) and Gynecologic Oncology (IF = 4.5) ranked second and third. Analysis of author A systematic analysis of authorship patterns in robotic gynecologic oncology surgery research reveals that 2,417 individual researchers have contributed to scholarly publications in this domain. The top ten contributing authors, ranked by publication volume, are presented in Table 4 6 Table 4 Top ten most prolific authors in robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025 TP TC AC Avg.Pub.Year Fig. 6 Co-authorship map of authors possessing ≥ 4 publications in robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025 Analysis of citation Bibliometric profiling of 561 publications on robotic gynecologic oncology surgery (2005–2025) uncovered a citation spectrum of 0–242, accumulating 13,597 citations in total. By imposing a ≥ 30 citation threshold, 143 high-impact articles were isolated for subsequent network visualization in VOSviewer (Fig. 7 5 6 Fig. 7 Network map of total citation analysis of documents with more than 30 citations, 2005–2025 Table 5 Top ten most total cited papers in robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025 TC TC per year Table 6 Top ten most local cited papers in robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025 LC TC LC/TC Analysis of references Co-citation reference landscapes were mapped with VOSviewer (Fig. 8 ) 7 8 Fig. 8 Visualization of reference data analysis in robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025 A B Table 7 Top ten most frequently cited references in robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025 LC Analysis of keyword In our bibliometric analysis of robotic surgery applications in gynecological oncology from 2005 to 2025, we identified 61 high-frequency keywords occurring ≥ 15 times across 561 articles. Co-occurrence analysis revealed four thematic clusters, each represented by a distinct color on the network map (Fig. 9 9 9 9 Fig. 9 Visualization of keywords data analysis in robotic gynecologic oncology surgery, 2005–2025. A B C Correlation analysis between economic statistical indicators and bibliometric indices Table 8 p p p p p p Table 8 Correlation analysis between economic statistical indicators and bibliometric indices in robotic gynecologic oncology surgery TP TC p p p Discussion This is a bibliometric analysis to identify papers on robotic surgery in gynecology oncology as well as to analyze their bibliometric characteristics. In this study, we used the WOSCC to find 561 relevant papers from 2005 to 2025. In line with previous bibliometric analyses exploring the adoption of robotic surgery across surgical disciplines [ 13 16 13 16 17 8 p p p 18 p 19 p p 18 Geographically, the scientific output on robot-assisted surgery for gynaecological cancers is imbalanced: while global interest is evident, scholarly production remains heavily concentrated in high-income regions. In our study, the hegemony of the United States (216/561 publications; 38.5%) is consistent with prior scientometric reports identifying North America as the epicenter of robotic innovation [ 13 14 16 8 16 8 15 20 Among institutions, Catholic University of the Sacred Heart (Italy) is the most productive institution (TP = 32), though its research initiation was relatively recent (2013). The Mayo Clinic in USA, while not the most productive in terms of publication volume (TP = 12), exhibits exceptional betweenness centrality (C = 0.16), positioning it as a primary knowledge broker within the global network. This role is crucial for the dissemination of innovative surgical techniques and best practices, aligning with the findings of previous bibliometric studies that highlight the importance of such intermediary institutions in accelerating the adoption of new technologies [ 13 8 Through journal data collection, we identified 114 journals publishing on robotic surgery in gynecologic oncology. Among them, Gynecologic Oncology International Journal of Gynecological Cancer Journal of Minimally Invasive Gynecology With respect to the authors, Professor Giovanni Scambia, from the Catholic University of the Sacred Heart (Italy), ranked first in the number of papers published, with 26 papers related to robotic surgery in gynecologic oncology. Author collaboration networks disclosed a cohesive but clustered community (143 core authors, 11 clusters), with Giovanni Scambia occupying a central position akin to the “hub-and-spoke” configuration reported for Alexandre Mottrie in general robotic surgery [ 13 20 Thematic analysis identified “endometrial cancer”, “radical hysterectomy”, and “lymphadenectomy” as dominant keywords, aligning with the keyword clusters reported by Levin et al. [ 8 14 20 21 Our study's findings, while showing a significant growth in the field, also reveal important gaps. The low percentage of randomized-controlled trials (RCTs) at 2.3% is concerning, as it is even lower than the 3.9% reported in other studies [ 8 14 21 8 Additionally, the near-absence of publications from low- and lower-middle-income countries (0%) contrasts sharply with the 8.4% contribution from middle-income nations in recent years [ 8 Furthermore, the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) with robotic platforms—an emerging hotspot identified by Song et al. [ 13 Recently, robotic gynecological oncology surgery has seen many exciting advances. The Da Vinci 5 model was granted the EU CE certification on August 1, 2025. This new generation of platform will integrate force feedback, AI-based navigation, and enhanced 3D visual effects to optimize the precision of complex anatomical operations (such as pelvic resection for advanced malignant tumors). While systems such as DEXTER® (Distalmotion) expand outpatient applications like sacrocolpopexy and myomectomy through streamlined workflows. Second, single-port robotics is emerging as a frontier for ultra-minimally invasive procedures [ 6 22 23 24 25 Limitations Although Web of Science Core Collection represents one of the most comprehensive academic databases, this bibliometric analysis exclusively relied on its indexed literature. Consequently, publications from non-Web of Science journals may have been omitted. Our search strategy emphasized core search terms (e.g., cancer types and "robotic surgery") to optimize the balance sensitivity and specificity. While this approach might have excluded studies focused on specific procedural techniques (such as lymph-node dissection), such omissions are not expected to impact the principal findings. Finally, given the continuous daily addition of new publications, the influence of recently released studies remains unaccounted for in this analysis. Conclusions Robotic surgery in gynecologic oncology has transitioned from a novel technique to a prolific research domain dominated by high-income nations and centered on endometrial cancer. The field must now pivot toward multi-center RCTs, global collaborations with low-resource settings, and integration of AI to consolidate its therapeutic promise and ensure equitable worldwide dissemination. Publisher's Note Springer Nature remains neutral with regard to jurisdictional claims in published maps and institutional affiliations. Author contributions XL and ML downloaded and analyzed the bibliometric data. XL wrote the initial draft of the manuscript. HC and XD assisted with data analysis and visualization. BL contributed to the interpretation of the results. CH supervised the project, provided critical feedback, and helped shape the research and manuscript. All authors reviewed and approved the final version of the manuscript. Funding Provincial key research and development program, 2023BEG01001. Data availability No datasets were generated or analysed during the current study. Declarations Conflict of interests The authors declare no competing interests. References 1. metadata.Title of this paper: Expanding robotic-assisted surgery in gynecology using the potential of an advanced robotic system
